ABSTRACT
Many of Brazil’s pre-salt basins are located in ultra-deep waters, and the high
heterogeneities of its offshore carbonate reservoirs make the extraction of representative
rock samples difficult, risky and expensive. Synthetic plugs are required to understand
oilfield properties and the behavior of oil in reservoirs where natural plugs cannot be
extracted. Specifically, in cases where it is necessary to reproduce representative
mineralogical and petrophysical characteristics from carbonates reservoir, it is evident that
there are a lack of publications focusing on synthetic plug construction. In this work, the
construction of synthetic plugs is studied, using a combination of published methodologies
to achieve an alternative construction of synthetic carbonate plugs for laboratory scale
studies. The obtained plugs used a procedure based on disintegrated rock matrices with
known particle sizes and particle size ratio, uniaxial compaction with controlled load force
and velocity, CaCO3 solubility control by changing temperature and pH and bonding
material. Consolidation, wettability and petrophysical properties of the synthetic plugs
were evaluated to characterize them. Generally, it was observed that the porosity and
permeability features of the synthetic plugs were within the range of carbonate reservoirs.
However, without reproducing a heterogeneous pore structure normally present in natural
samples. On the other hand, wettability properties of the resulted synthetic plugs were
similar to the natural carbonate plugs. Further studies are necessary to obtain more
similar chemical and petrophysical properties to the natural samples.
Keywords: synthetic, carbonate, plugs, petroleum, petrophysics, wettability, consolidation
RESUMO
A localização em águas ultra profundas das reservas petrolíferas do pré-sal brasileiro e
a alta heterogeneidade dos seus reservatórios carbonáticos dificultam a aquisição de
uma amostra de rocha representativa, além de ser uma operação de risco e de alto
dispêndio. Plugues sintéticos são utilizados para compreensão das propriedades dos
campos petrolíferos e para avaliação do comportamento dos hidrocarbonetos em
reservatórios onde plugues reais não podem ser adquiridos. Especificamente, nos casos
onde são necessários reproduzir características representativas mineralógicas e
petrofísicas dos reservatórios carbonáticos, sendo notório a falta de publicações voltada
para construção de plugues sintéticos. No presente trabalho, estudou-se a construção de
plugues sintéticos empregando metodologias já difundidas, visando a construção de
plugues carbonáticos sintéticos para utilização em escala laboratorial. Os plugues obtidos
foram construídos utilizando matrizes de rochas desintegradas com tamanhos e
proporções de partículas conhecidos, compactação uniaxial com força e velocidades
controladas e controle de solubilidade de CaCO3, variando apenas temperatura, pH e
proporções de material cimentante. Foram avaliadas as propriedades petrofísicas, a
molhabilidade e a consolidação dos plugues sintéticos para posterior caracterização dos
mesmos. Comumente, observou-se que os valores de porosidade e permeabilidade dos
plugues sintéticos se encontravam dentro do intervalo de valores obtidos em
reservatórios carbonáticos reais. No entanto, não reproduziram a estrutura heterogênea
dos poros, normalmente presente em amostras de rochas naturais. Em contrapartida, as
propriedades de molhabilidade dos plugues sintéticos se apresentaram análogas aos
plugues de rochas carbonáticas naturais. Estudos complementares são necessários para
obtenção de propriedades químicas e petrofísicas mais próximas das amostras reais.
Palavras-chave: sinteticos, carbonatos, plugues, petroleo, petrofisica, molhabilidade, consolidação

1 INTRODUCTION
The study of petroleum reservoirs from plugs has a long importance dating back to
the beginning of the oil and gas industry. Plugs are cylindrical rocks with specific
dimensions about 3.8 cm in diameter and a height 1.5 times greater than the diameter,
extracted by drilling from reservoirs (CONSENTINO, 2001). Due to the representative in-
situ characteristics such as mineralogical composition and petrophysical properties
(CONSENTINO, 2001), plugs are used to understand at a laboratory scale the behavior
and interaction of the reservoir rocks and fluids in a production system (GAAFAR;
TEWARI; ZAIN, 2015; ALOTAIBI; AZMY; NASR-EL-DIN, 2010). For example, Svec and
Grigg (2001), used plugs to study the enhance oil recovery during an injection of water
alternating gas; Howe et al. (2015) flowed surfactants through plugs to study changes in
oil production; Zamirian et al. (2014) reported new techniques for measuring
permeabilities under in-situ conditions using plugs.
In cases such as the Brazilian Presalt carbonate reservoirs, heterogeneity and high
depths (PIZARRO; BRANCO, 2012; BARBASSA, 2007) make it difficult to obtain reservoir
plugs. Due to this challenge, commercial plugs (SANNI, 2013; CHURCHER et al, 1991)
or synthetic plugs constructed in the laboratory (TAREK 2014; GREAVES et al, 1996;
BERNARD, 1967; FURRE; HOLT, 1995) may be used. Some research works can be
found in the literature relating about the construction of this plugs, but in contrast to the
sandstone reservoirs (WANG et al, 2008; RAIMONDI; TORCASO, 1964; ANBAH;
CHILINGAR; BEESON, 1965), there is a lack of publications that focus on the construction
of representative carbonates that consider both mineralogical composition and
petrophysical properties such as porosity and permeability.
In this sense, the contribution of this work is to study a methodology to construct
synthetic carbonate plugs, using a combination of published methodologies aiming to
reproduce the mineralogy and control the petrophysics properties similar to the natural
samples, in order to enable the generation of promising studies to understand the oil and
gas reservoirs, such as the Brazilian Presalt.

1.1 OBJECTIVE
To study a methodology to construct synthetic carbonate plugs aiming to reproduce
the mineralogy and control the petrophysics properties similar to the natural samples.

2 LITERATURE REVIEW
2.1 CARBONATE NATURAL ROCK PROPERTIES
In order to construct synthetic plugs with similar properties to natural rocks, it was
necessary to screening properties of natural carbonate samples. Plugs are formed by
carbonates or sandstones, which are the main conforming types of rock in oil and gas
exploration areas (EHRENBERG; NADEAU, 2005). These two types of rocks have
significant differences. The former is the sediment production location, and the latter is
the higher chemical reactivity due to the carbonate mineral (PIZARRO; BRANCO, 2012).
One of the know carbonate rock found in the Brazilian Presalt is the dolomite rock (JING
et al., 2012; BOYD et al., 2015). Due to the rock chemistry, wettability properties of
carbonate rocks are different of sandstone rocks. Wettability can be explained as the
preference of a solid surface to be in contact with a fluid in the presence of other
immiscible fluids (ANDERSON, 1986). Wettability of a solid surface can be preferentially
hydrophilic (water-wet) or hydrophobic (oil-wet). Literature reports wettability of natural
carbonate rocks to be intermediate and oil-wet (PIZARRO; BRANCO, 2012; MANRIQUE
et al., 2004; MASALMEH et al., 2014; AL-DHAHLI et al., 2011; AKKURT et al., 2000),
contrary to the known water-wet for sandstone rocks (PENTLAND et al., 2010; CHATZIS
et al., 1988).
Petrophysical characteristics are important in the evaluation and characterization
of oilfields rocks (QIN et al., 2018). Petrophysics is defined as the study of physical,
electrical and mechanical properties and rock-fluid interaction in a petroleum system
(CHEN; PAGAN, 2013). In this work, it was studied the physical properties porosity and
permeability in the synthetic plugs, in order to understand how to control and reproduce
these properties similar to the samples found in oilfield. In this sense, it is important to
mention that petrophysic properties of natural carbonate rocks are heterogeneous and
highly variable, due to the combination of micro-porosities, intergranular porosities, vuggy
porosities and fracture porosities (MURPHY et al., 1996). Table 2.1 presents the
petrophysical properties of some carbonate Brazilian Presalt oilfields, in order to evidence

2.2 CONSTRUCTION OF SYNTHETIC PLUGS
A selection of papers was screened by using the following keywords: lithology
(carbonate), rock sampling (plug or core) and sample feature (synthetic or artificial). Only
papers focused on the use of such samples for the petroleum engineering area, and the
ones where the construction methodology could be identified, were considered. In
addition, some undergraduate and master's degree works were analyzed.
2.3 MATERIALS AND CONTENTS USED TO CONSTRUCT SYNTHETIC PLUGS
Due to the relationship between the rock chemistry and the material used to
construct synthetic plugs, it was important to identify the main materials and their contents
which were used to construct such samples, independent of the approach used for their
construction, such us uniaxial compression, cementing of materials, sintering and others.
In this way, it was possible to identify 10 different materials and theirs contents.

From Table 2.2, it is possible to identify the materials content range from 50% to
100% (w/w) of the synthetic plugs. Note that from these 10 materials, 6 correspond to
sand matrices, and the rest include crushed formation rock, CaCO3, bentonites and
kaolinites. Most of these selected studies were therefore based on the construction of
sandstone plugs. There are two likely reasons for this finding. The first is that constructing
a porous media with a naturally granulated material, with known particle size, is fast and
easy. The second is that because it is a porous media, it allows studies with no influence
of chemical reactivity, due to the simple chemical composition of the sand (silicon and
oxygen) (WEINAN et al., 1997).
Regarding the approach for construction of carbonate plugs, it was possible to
identify four works that used a carbonate matrix material and its content (ANBAH;
CHILINGAR; BEESON, 1965; FEDRIZZI et al., 2018; WANG et al. 2017; LUO et al.
2018). For example, Anbah; Chilingar and Beeson (1965) used calcite flour as its main
component material (95% w/w), carbonate plugs were constructed for the application of
24
electrical current to increase the flow rate of oil and water in a porous media, however
petrophysical properties were not reproduced or correlated with the presented
methodology. From another approach, Fedrizzi et al. (2018) related the construction of
carbonate rocks using calcite, sand, Portland cement and water. In this work, it was
investigated the main petrophysical characteristics of these samples and the relationship
with the amount of cementing material, however this study did not consider the possible
heterogeneous porous structure of natural carbonate rocks. The construction of
representative synthetic carbonate plugs requires special pore studies considerations that
it was not studied by Fedrizzi et al. (2018).
Wang et al. (2017), during the construction process, embedded NaCl grains of
average particle size of 3mm and aluminum foils with radius of 1.5 mm and a thickness of
20 µm into a blend of carbonate drilling cuttings and epoxy resin. Then, the embedded
materials were leached out by immersing the consolidated synthetic plug in 75 ºC water
and 4% NaOH (sodium hydroxide) alkali solution respectively. The use of these materials
and procedures simulates vuggy (due to the NaCl) and crack (due to the aluminum foils)
pores into the samples. Their observation indicated that secondary pores crack and vuggy
are important factors to control the permeability of the synthetic plugs. It was observed
that increasing the quantity of NaCl grains the permeability increases with the increase of
total porosity, contrary to the observed with aluminum foils which decrease the
permeability and increase the porosity, increasing the quantity of aluminum foil used.
However, it is necessary to develop a better understand about the pore structure and the
influence of the quantity of epoxy resin and particle size drilling cuttings in the
petrophysical properties. Additionally, the chemical nature of epoxy resin as bonding
material could change the chemical properties of the constructed samples, fact that can
affect the fluid-rock interaction tests, such as, wettability measurements.
Therefore, using the same base material, Luo et al. (2018) prepared drill cuttings
with toluene as a packing fluid and then, they applied a compression press of 5000 psi for
30 minutes to consolidate the synthetic plugs. As the main objective of this research was
the evaluation of formation damage using synthetic plugs, the influence of compression
press and drill cuttings particle properties in the petrophysical properties was not
identified. In this sense, despite of mineralogical properties of the constructed plugs may
25
be similar to the found in a specific field, these analog samples not guarantee the
reproduction and control of similar petrophysical properties of the natural plugs.
Additional papers were identified that used a non-carbonate matrix material, such
as sands, but using cementing procedures to allow the calcium carbonate precipitation on
them. Melo, (2012), evaluated a quartz sand (50% w/w) cemented in a medium favorable
to precipitation of calcium carbonate to simulate a carbonate medium. The aim was to
evaluate the geochemical interactions with a reactive fluid for carbon dioxide geological
storage purposes. The findings and discussion about these approaches will be detailed in
the following sections.
According to Tiab and Donaldson (2004), petrophysical properties of rocks depend
on the particle size, amount of cementation and compaction. For this reason, the next
analyses from this literature review will be focused on these parameters.

pore volume is dependent on the volume of particle, and therefore also dependent on its

2.5 METHODOLOGIES FOR CONSOLIDATION OF SYNTHETIC PLUGS
The methodology used for consolidation of the plugs was categorized into five
groups: Group 1: unconsolidated samples; Group 2: consolidated by compaction; Group
3: consolidated by bonding materials; Group 4: consolidated by material solubility or
precipitation; Group 5: consolidated by materials sintering and Group 6: consolidated by
3D-printed. Following items present the mentioned groups.
2.5.1 Group 1 – Unconsolidated samples
A rock plug sample may be unconsolidated, as with unconsolidated sand,
depending on the oilfield properties as in the case of Wang et al. (2008). For this reason,
after a particle size analysis of reservoir rock particles, the author mixed sands of sizes
between 0.4 and 0.125 mm, and this was used to represent the reservoir zone of interest.
Another material conforming to unconsolidated plugs was found (HASHMAT et al.,
2016). Here, packed glass beads of different sizes were used to study the chemical
interaction of fluids within the porous media. The author justified the control of porosities
and permeabilities due to the use of glass beads and its physical standard characteristics.
Based on the same packaging principle quartz sand of size 0.595-0.297 mm was used,
packed in a stainless-steel tube and sterilized at 165 ° C for 3 hours. The sample was
used for a fluid displacement test (XU; LU, 2011).
2.5.2 Group 2 – Consolidation by compaction
Within the consolidated samples, compaction was identified as one of the
methodologies with greater application. Here, a load to the plug can be exerted in a
uniaxial or triaxial way. For example, by mixing particles of sand with shale in different
proportions and applying a uniaxial compaction within a metallic cell. As a result, a
consolidated rock sample can be obtained and used to analyze the dielectric constants of
the rocks (WEINAN et al., 1997).
32
In this same way, it was proposed to obtain consolidated synthetic plugs by using
unconsolidated reservoir rock samples (LUQUOT et al., 2016). The samples were
disintegrated manually to guarantee the same particle size of natural unconsolidated rock.
In the mentioned work, the aim was to compare the porosity, particle size and internal
structure of unconsolidated and synthetic plugs. It was concluded that both samples had
similar properties. In addition, it can be emphasized that in this way, it is possible to
guarantee a natural sample reproduction.
2.5.3 Group 3 – Consolidation by bonding materials
One of the first methodologies regarding the consolidation of plugs using bonding
materials was reported in 1999 (THOMPSON et al., 1999). This consolidation was
achieved by applying a uniaxial force into a mixture of quartz and epoxy resin, during the
curing process of the epoxy. These constructed plugs were used to evaluate the
compressive strength of the plugs. It is noteworthy that properties such as porosity and
permeability of these plugs were not evaluated due to its geophysics application studies.
Subsequently, based on previous methodology by Thompson et al. (1999),
sandstone rock plugs were constructed by Tarek (2014) aiming to simulate reservoir
conditions and evaluate the xanthan gum effect on water production. Portland cement
was used instead as a bonding material. The composition of the sandstone samples was
74% (w/w) sand, with particle sizes of 0.71 mm, 0.5 mm and 0.25 mm. The mixture
consisted of 14.8% (w/w) Portland cement and 11.1% (w/w) water.
On the other hand, other authors developed an equipment called EDR - Radial
Displacement Equipment, Londoño (2010) apud Celis and Fernandez (2012) and Alarcon
and Cavanzo (2013), which allowed them to simulate the physical behaviour of water and
steam injection processes in synthetic sandstone rocks. For such, synthetic samples were
constructed using sand and polyester resin as a bonding material, however, without
control of petrophysical properties.
Based on the previous methodology of Londoño (2010), a methodology for plug
construction with controlled petrophysics properties (porosity and permeability) was
developed, by mixing different quantities of sand, white kaolin and resin epoxy (CELIS;
33
FERNANDEZ, 2012). The author concluded that a greater amount of binder material
caused lower porosities and permeabilities. Alarcon and Cavanzo (2013) adapted the
methodology used by Celis and Fernandez (2012) by using a manual compaction
procedure that allowed synthetic plugs with different petrophysics properties to be
obtained, although without the control of the manual applied force.
Therefore, using the same homogenized material of Alarcon and Cavanzo (2013),
Padron and Lizcano (2014) standardized the compaction process by applying controlled
uniaxial torques, resulting in a greater reproducibility and repeatability of the petrophysical
properties of the samples.
Caceres and Porras (2015) focused their research on constructing electro-
pneumatic equipment that produced a more controlled and higher compaction than those
obtained by Padron and Lizcano (2014). In this sense, the authors developed a
methodology correlating the applied pressure and mixture composition (sand, white
kaolin, epoxy resin and water). It was concluded that samples manufactured with 100 psi,
using kaolin and sand with particle size of 0.149-0.074 mm, presented an excellent
consolidation. Additionally, porosities between 21 to 33%, and permeabiities between 40
to 470 mD, were observed. Consequently, the authors recommended the construction of
high pressure equipment to obtain samples with lower petrophysical properties.
2.5.4 Group 4 – Consolidation by material solubility or precipitation
Within the synthetic plug construction, the consolidation by precipitation of silica
and carbonate materials was identified.
Holt et al. (2003) and Brignoli et al. (1998) describe precipitation, and subsequent
consolidation, of silica by CO2 flowing in a homogeneous sand and sodium silicate
solution, which was subsequently subjected to uniaxial and confinement pressure. The
authors concluded that samples had weak mechanical properties. In turn, they emphasize
that due to the particle size distribution and precipitated material quantity, it will be possible
to control the petrophysical properties.
From another consolidation perspective by calcium carbonate, two types of
methodologies were identified: use of bacteria (biologically induced precipitation) and
34
enzyme-induced precipitation. A biologically induced precipitation, with a petroleum
engineering application, was described in Ferris et al. (1992). This consolidation method
employed a flow of solution consisting of Bacillus pasteurii NRS 673 bacteria, Difco
nutrient, ammonium chloride, sodium bicarbonate, anhydrous calcium chloride and
distilled water. Additionally, solvent and water stability precipitation were noted. The
authors describe a permeability reduction on porous media, due to the carbonate
precipitation. In addition, this paper emphasizes that this carbonate acted like two agents:
cementer and obstructer.
Van-paassen et al. (2009) described some of the improvements that are obtained
implementing the biologically induced carbonate precipitation. In this sense, regarding
construction of experimental plugs, the author used sand with a density of 1560 kg/m3
added into a suspension solution of ureolitic bacteria "sporosarcina pasteurii", urea and
calcium chloride. After the treatment, five sample blocks were extracted by drilling, and
cylindrical rock plugs with a fixed porosity value were obtained.
Kucharski et al. (1996 and 1997) apud Al-Shahri et al. (2010), Yasuhara et al.
(2012) and Ronan (2005) describe a controlled calcium carbonate precipitation process
around silicon sand. This process simulated a natural cementation rock, and used a
patented aqueous solution flow at low pressure. This method titled “CIPS - Calcite in-situ
precipitation system” allowed synthetic sample permeability control until a given condition.
Ismail et al. (2000), based on the CIPS patent, developed a technique for artificially
cemented calcareous soil preparation, looking for a high cementing quality and consistent
density of the sample.
Besides, Yasuhara et al. (2012) creates another method, justifying the CIPS
unknown patent solutions and the complex management of containment, extinction and
generation of bacteria. The author describes a precipitation method using urease, urea
and calcium chloride. After testing this method, it was concluded that further studies are
needed to understand how permeability and resistance can be restricted, controlling the
amount of precipitated calcium carbonate.
Another method based on carbonate precipitation was described by Melo (2012),
adapting the Brazilian standard “NBR 7182: Construction of compacted soil samples”
ABNT (1986) to construct a synthetic rock plug to study the behaviour of this sample in
35
the presence of hydrochloric acid, aiming at carbon capture CO2 storage studies. For this
reason, a quartz sand sample was cemented using a homogeneous aqueous calcium
hydroxide and calcified green algae (halimeda), using a proportion of 50%, 25% and 25%,
respectively. Subsequently, the sample was compacted and carbonated with CO2. From
this work is important to note the author’s emphasis on carbonate mineralogical
reproduction, despite not reproducing petrophysical properties.
Pei et al. (2016) aiming to study seismic physical modelling, construct synthetic
sandstone plugs applying a load force over a blend of quartz sand with controlled particle
size (from 0,6 mm to 0,02 mm) and epoxy resin. The authors explain that changes in the
porosity of the synthetic plugs, probably, occurs due the described particles size and the
applied load force used to consolidate the sample, but, a relationship between these
construction parameters and the obtained porosities was not identified.
2.5.5 Group 5 – Consolidation by materials sintering
Manière et al. (2017) describes a sintering process that involves a compacting heat
treatment to transform powder into a solid material by the union of its particles. For this,
heat treatments are required close to the material melting temperature. Some materials
were found as a basis of consolidation by thermal sintering of materials: PTFE
(Polytetrafluoroethylene) or Teflon and quartz.
Mccaffery and Bennion (1974) describes the methodology for constructing plugs
by using PTFE or Teflon particles previously compressed in a mould, where a temperature
of 371°C was applied for a sintering process to occur. Anderson (1986) explains that
Teflon guarantees an inert chemical composition and low surface energy, resulting on
wettability control.
Weinbrandt et al. (1969) and Farley et al. (1970) apud Mccaffery and Bennion
(1974) indicate that porous media and surface of sintering PTFE samples appear like
sandstone rocks. They claim this due to its pore structures at microscopic scale, rough
and irregular surfaces, and uniform porosities and permeabilities. However, they did not
elaborate on the surface chemical composition.
36
Ranjbar et al. (1992) describes the production of porous models by quartz particle
sintering, with particle sizes between 0.04 and 0.07 mm. The author justifies the use of
this technique due to the easy cleaning procedure and reuse advantage. No concerns
about mineralogical and petrophysical parameters control were considered.
2.5.6 Group 6 – Consolidation by 3D-printed
From another approach, Kong et al. (2018) manufactured synthetic plugs using 3-
D printed gypsum rock and evaluated its physical properties through quantitative porosity
analyses. Their observation indicated that these manufacture rocks host spherical pores
and fewer blade-shaped pores, evidencing a homogeneous pore structure. In contrast,
additionally to the mentioned by the authors about the limitation of replicate similar natural
rock pore frame due to the printing resolution, it can be noted that the use of gypsum
powder may not represent a complex mineralogizes found in plugs from field. In this
sense, it can be another limitation of these synthetic samples when submitted to
interaction rock-fluid tests.
In a summary, the construction of synthetic carbonate plugs is viable and
dependent on the selected materials and methodologies. Therefore, there is a lack of
researches focusing both mineralogical composition and petrophysical properties to
reproduce a heterogeneous but controlled pore structure and chemical composition
characteristics typical of carbonate oilfield rocks. In this way, this research presents a
promising approach to obtain such plugs, aiming to contribute to the evidenced research
lack.

3 PROPOSAL FOR CARBONATE PLUG CONSTRUCTION
Plug composition has a direct relationship with the rock chemistry, and therefore
with the behavior of the sample in the laboratory tests focused on the surface chemistry
behavior, such as wettability measurements aimed at enhanced oil recovery studies.
According to Abdallah et al. (2007), wettability refers to the preference of a solid
surface to be in contact with a fluid, due to the equilibrium of interstitial forces (fluid-solid).
In the case of a petroleum reservoir, these forces will generate a system with preferences
to be oil-wet or water-wet due to the behavior between oil, water and reservoir rock. This
means that due to the wettability, if reservoir rock is oil-wet, higher amounts of oil can
remain retained inside the reservoir rock, resulting in a negative economic situation
(ALOTAIBI et al., 2010). For example, in the case of sandstone rocks, preferences to be
water-wet (PENTLAND et al., 2010; CHATZIS et al., 1988) were found, and carbonate
rocks to be oil-wet (MANRIQUE et al., 2004; MASALMEH et al., 2014; PIZARRO;
BRANCO, 2012) or with an intermediate wet behavior (AL-DHAHLI et al., 2011; AKKURT
et al., 2000) were found.
Because these plugs can be also used for advanced petrophysics studies, such as
flooding or wetting measurements, it is important to choose materials which allow
synthetic carbonate samples to be built, guaranteeing their similarity to the natural ones,
such as in studies of changing wettabilities due to the application of chemical treatments
to the rock-fluid system in order to enhance oil production.
To achieve carbonate reservoir samples that reproduce the proper mineral
chemistry composition, materials based on silicas and sand, as well as bonding materials
based on epoxy, resins and cements, will not be considered. Therefore, based on the
developed methodologies by Lakatos et al. (2003) and Luquot et al. (2016), which used a
disintegrated rock material to obtain a core plug, an adaptation is proposed that uses a
disintegrated dolomitic carbonate rock. In this way, disintegrated carbonate rock will be
the base material of synthetic plugs, guaranteeing a similar natural composition compared
to the corresponding reservoir rock. Based on the previously particle size analysis by
literature, a particle size control in five intervals around the most used granulometry was
38
proposed, aiming to obtain plugs with different basic petrophysical parameters. They
were: 0.3-0.6 mm, 0.15-0.3 mm, 0.074-0.15 mm, 0.020-0.074 mm and<0.020 mm.
Additionally, it is proposed to use during the construction process some bonding
materials in low content and the increasing calcium carbonate solubility followed by
precipitation, in order to generate a natural bonding material into the particles used to
construct the synthetic plugs. Figure 3 presents the related solubility due to the decreasing

4 MATERIALS AND METHODS
4.1 BASE MATERIAL - DISINTEGRATED DOLOMITIC CARBONATE
The base material used in this work to construct synthetic plugs was a
disintegrated dolomitic carbonate rock with controlled particle size. The base material was
disintegrated first by a jaw crusher and then by a roller crusher. Chemical analysis of the
dolomitic carbonate rock used was carried out by X-ray spectrometry fluorescence in the
STD-1 (Standardless) calibration, concerning the analysis of chemical elements between
fluorine and uranium. In addition, the loss on ignition (LOI) was carried out at 1020 °C for
2 hours.
Then, to obtain particle size intervals from 0.3-0.6 mm, 0.15-0.3 mm, 0.074-0.15
mm, 0.02-0.074mm, and<0.02 mm, sieves with a known mesh (0.02mm, 0.074mm,
0.15mm, 0.3mm and 0.6mm) were used.
In cases where the quantity of the finest particle size (<0.02 mm) obtained was too
low, particle size 0.02-0.074 mm were sampled and pulverized in a Herzog pulverizer to
obtain the needed material. To corroborate the true size of the finest particle material
resulting from this procedure, a low angle laser light scattering measurement (Malvern
Mastersizer) was used to assure particle size.

4.3 METHODOLOGIES TO EVALUATE SYNTHETIC PLUGS
4.3.1 Immersion tests
120 hours after removing from compression moulding, samples were submitted to
a water immersion test for 12 hours to evaluate their stability related to consolidation. The
main aim was to verify if such samples would not have disintegrated in this medium, which
can be used in routine plug tests such as spontaneous imbibition, fluid displacement and
saturation tests (GAAFAR et al., 2015). Photographic register of samples was done
during, and 1 hour after the test. After the test, the samples were handled to verify their
consolidation.
4.3.2 Wettability measurements
Air-water and air-mineral oil contact angle measurements were done using a DSA
100 Kruss drop shape analyzer at room pressure and temperature conditions.
Measurements were done on samples with a disk geometry. A drop of distilled water or
mineral oil was placed on the flat surface of the sample and the contact angle was
measured immediately and after 10 seconds.
43
4.3.3 Gas porosimetry
Gas porosimetry is a technique based on the gas expansion which allows the
measurement of either pore or grain volume, grain density and permeability of a rock
sample (DE OLIVEIRA et al., 2016). Before the test, synthetic plugs of full size (Figure 4,
the part A) were dried for 24 hours in an oven at 60C with controlled humidity of 45%.
Plugs were submitted to porosity and permeability gas (nitrogen) test with a confinement
pressure of 2400 psi in an Ultrapore 300 porosimeter and Ultraperm 500 permeameter.
Klikenber effect was corrected to obtain porosities and permeabilities results. Grain
density is a measure of mass per unit of volume of the elemental composition and internal
bonding materials of rocks (Schön, 2011). From this technique grain density can be also
obtained.
4.3.4 Mercury injection porosimetry
A Micromeritics AutoPore IV mercury porosimeter was used to estimate the pore
size distribution of the synthetic samples, porosity, permeability and grain density. Due to
the limitation of sample size of the technique, full size plugs cannot be analyzed. In this
sense, from plugs of full size used for the gas porosimetry test, it was necessary to extract
a fragment rock to be study. For this reason, plugs were cut in 3 disk of 13.3 ± 0.1 mm
height and extracted a fragment rock of 20 ± 0.1 mm width from the central disk. (Figure
4, the part B). Synthetic plugs were cutting off carefully to avoid alterations of the pore
space. After this, extracted fragments were dried for 24 hours in an oven at 100ºC and
weight. This value was used as input data in the porosimeter software. A maximum
intrusion mercury pressure of 40000 psi was used in all the tests.

Grain density of the synthetic plugs were measured by gas and mercury
porosimetry and are presented in the Table 5.3. It is expected that the main contribution
to the grain density of the synthetic plugs corresponded to the base material used to
construction. Thus, the expected grain density corresponds to the related in the literature
for dolomite rocks 2,84 g/cm3 (D.M.D., 2018). Due to the low density of the wax, synthetic
plugs using bonding material showed lower grain density in comparison with the one
constructed without it. This expected behavior was confirmed with the resultant grain
densities by gas and mercury porosimetry, where samples with bonding material shows
an average of 2,64 and 2,62 g/cm3, and sample without bonding material (P10) of 2,87
and 2,84 g/cm3, respectively.
Table 5.3 presents the theoretical (item 4.3.5) and experimental petrophysics
results obtained by gas and mercury porosimetry and its relative error, based on the
theoretical value. From here, based on the theoretical porosity calculated for synthetic
plugs with bonding material, it was observed expected values from 12.99% to 19.88% for
particle size ratio 1:1 and 12.41% to 18.31% for particle size ratio 1:3. In this sense, it was
not observed evidences of relationship between porosity and the particle size ratios.
70
Subsequently, a tendency to the decreasing of porosity with the decrease of
particle sizes used to construct the synthetic plugs was observed. Considering the
previously explained calculus, theoretical porosity has a direct relationship with the
volume of the sample and grain density. In this sense, considering that all the constructed
synthetic plugs have a similar grain density, the calculated porosity was influenced by the
observed decreasing heights (Table 5.2) with the increasing of the particle size. It due to
the packing of the particles used to construct the synthetic plugs. In this way, the largest
the particle size, the higher the difference of size between particles. It causes a better
pack of the smaller particles into the empty spaces between the larger particles, thus
reducing the bulk volume occupied by the particles. Additionally, it is important to mention
that comparing the synthetic plugs with and without (P10) bonding material, it was
observed that maximum porosities are obtained in the absence of the commercial amide
wax, with a value of 19,71%, probably because the bonding material is not entering into
the pore spaces of the plug.
To generate a better understand of the pore structure and therefor porosities and
permeabilities, the correlation between experimental tests were discussed following.
Based in the observed tendency of theoretical porosity, it was analyzed the
experimental petrophysical results obtained from gas and mercury porosimetry. The same
tendency to decrease porosity with the decreasing of particle sizes used to construct the
synthetic plugs was observed for the experimental test. In this way, porosities of the
constructed plugs with bonding materials was found from 10.43% to 17.23% and 10.32%
to 14.67% for particle size ratio 1:1 and 1:3 w/w respectively, based on the gas
porosimetry and values and values from 11.27% to 19.96% and 11.39% to 15.36% for
particles size ratios 1:1 and 1:3 w/w respectively, based on the mercury porosimetry.
Additionally, it was observed higher relative errors from the gas porosimetry compared to
the mercury porosimetry. It can be due probably to the higher intrusion pressure applied
by the mercury porosimetry than gas porosimetry, allowing the identification of smaller
pore sizes.
On the other hand, based on the permeability results obtained by the two
experimental techniques, it was observed a tendency to increase permeabilities with the
71
increasing of particle size, contrary to the found for the porosity. To explain these

6 CONCLUSIONS
In this study, consolidated synthetic carbonate plugs were obtained using
disintegrated carbonate rock matrix with controlled particle sizes and particle size ratios,
water content of pH 3 (6% w/w relative to the base material), commercial amide wax as
bonding material (5% w/w relative to the base material), drying temperature of 100ºC for
1 hour, and uniaxial compaction with controlled load force (200kN) and velocity (25
mm/min).The approach of construct disk samples was useful for the screening of the
different parameters before the construction of the real size plugs.
Generally, it was observed that the porosity and permeability features of the
synthetic plugs were within the range of carbonate reservoirs. However, without
reproducing a heterogeneous pore structure normally present in natural samples. On the
other hand, wettability properties of the resulted synthetic plugs were similar to the natural
carbonate plugs.
Regardless the porous heterogeneous structure of natural carbonate samples, an
attempt to relate particle size and petrophysical characteristics of the synthetic plugs was
presented. In this sense, synthetic carbonate plugs can be reproduced correlating a
disintegrated carbonate rock matrix.
Considering the limitations of the existing methodologies to construct synthetic
carbonate plugs, the presented methodology demonstrates a promising way to be
explored in order to generate further studies to understand carbonate oilfields. This
promising result makes viable the construction of synthetic carbonate plugs and the use
of this samples in laboratory tests where petrophysical properties of the sample are not a
concern, which is not the case of core flooding tests.
81
7 FUTURE WORKS
With the purpose of construct a more representative plug similar to the natural
ones, a combination of methodologies to generate heterogeneous pore structures and
higher petrophysics properties should be explored. Additionally, it is suggested to use
drilling cuttings from carbonate reservoirs as base material to construct synthetic plugs.
On the other hand, the constructed carbonate plugs should be compared with
natural samples to evaluate the behavior of this synthetic samples in tests such as
advanced petrophysics studies such as core flooding.
